8 Quadratic form

8.1 Definition and matrix representation of quadratic form

For homogeneous linear equations, it can be recorded in matrix form more conveniently and directly. However, for polynomials with cross terms and quadratic terms, quadratic forms need to be used to express them in matrix form for easy calculation.
For example, for the following polynomial:ax2+2bxy+cy2ax^2+2bxy+cy^2ax2+2bxy+cy2This can be written in matrix form:[xy][abbc][xy]\begin{bmatrix} x&y\\ \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} a&b\\ b&c\\ \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x\\ y\\ \end{bmatrix}[x​y​][ab​bc​][xy​]
After calculating this equation, you can get the initial polynomial:ax2+2bxy+cy2ax^2+2bxy+cy^2ax2+2bxy+cy2. Furthermore, the formula can be simplified toxTAxx^T A xxTAx

Then we can further derive the definition of the quadratic form: the quadratic form is a quadratic homogeneous polynomial about multiple variables. formal:Q(x)=xTAxQ(x) = x^T A xQ(x)=xTAxin:

  • x=(x1,x2,…,xn)Tx = (x_1, x_2, \dots, x_n)^Tx=(x1​,x2​,…,xn​)Tis a vector of variables
  • AAAis a symmetric matrix (when real quadratic)
  • Q(x)Q(x)Q(x)It’s the quadratic form

Expanded form: ifA=[a11a12⋯a1na12a22⋯a2n⋮⋮⋱⋮a1na2n⋯ann]A = \begin{bmatrix} a_{11} & a_{12} & \cdots & a_{1n} \\ a_{12} & a_{22} & \cdots & a_{2n} \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ a_{1n} & a_{2n} & \cdots & a_{nn} \end{bmatrix}A=​a11​a12​⋮a1n​​a12​a22​⋮a2n​​⋯⋯⋱⋯​a1n​a2n​⋮ann​​​SoQ(x)=a11x12+a22x22+⋯+annxn2+2a12x1x2+⋯+2aijxixjQ(x) = a_{11}x_1^2 + a_{22}x_2^2 + \cdots + a_{nn}x_n^2 + 2a_{12}x_1x_2 + \cdots + 2a_{ij}x_ix_jQ(x)=a11​x12​+a22​x22​+⋯+ann​xn2​+2a12​x1​x2​+⋯+2aij​xi​xj​Diagonal elements correspond to square terms, and off-diagonal elements correspond to cross terms.

In practice, the matrixAAAis the most important and can even be used to represent quadratic forms.
In two dimensions, a quadratic form is of the formQ(x,y)=ax2+bxy+cy2Q(x,y) = ax^2 + bxy + cy^2Q(x,y)=ax2+bxy+cy2function. Among them, there arexyxyxyThe terms are called cross terms.

  • Its equivalent curve is often a quadratic curve (ellipse, hyperbola, parabola).
  • In three dimensions and higher, it corresponds to quadratic surfaces (ellipsoid, hyperboloid, etc.).

8.2 Preparation method and standard type

8.2.1 Preparation method

The goal of the formula method is to convert the quadratic form into the form of a sum of squares and eliminate the cross terms through a step-by-step "recipe". Its basic idea:

  1. Select a pair of variables with a cross term, for example2ax1x22a x_1 x_22ax1​x2​。
  2. Combine related terms into a perfect square:ax12+2bx1x2+cx22=a(x1+bax2)2+(c−b2a)x22ax_1^2 + 2b x_1 x_2 + c x_2^2 = a\left(x_1 + \frac{b}{a}x_2\right)^2 + \left(c - \frac{b^2}{a}\right)x_2^2ax12​+2bx1​x2​+cx22​=a(x1​+ab​x2​)2+(c−ab2​)x22​3. Formulate the variables in turn until all cross terms are eliminated, and an expression containing only square terms is obtained, with a form similar to:f(x)=λ1y12+λ2y22+⋯+λnyn2f(x) = \lambda_1 y_1^2 + \lambda_2 y_2^2 + \dots + \lambda_n y_n^2f(x)=λ1​y12​+λ2​y22​+⋯+λn​yn2​in{yi}\{y_i\}{yi​}is the new variable after linear transformation.

8.2.2 Standard type

Definition: Convert the quadratic form into a diagonal form without cross terms through the matching method or contract transformation:f(x)∼λ1y12+λ2y22+⋯+λnyn2f(x) \sim \lambda_1 y_1^2 + \lambda_2 y_2^2 + \dots + \lambda_n y_n^2f(x)∼λ1​y12​+λ2​y22​+⋯+λn​yn2​Features:

  • coefficientλi\lambda_iλi​is called the standard form coefficient of the quadratic form.
  • The distribution of signs of these coefficients (positive, negative, zero) determines the properties of the quadratic form.

8.3 Positive definite matrix and discriminant criterion (Sylvester discriminant method)

8.3.1 Positive definite matrix

real symmetric matrixAAAis called a positive definite matrix, if for any non-zero vectorx∈Rnx \in \mathbb{R}^nx∈Rn, both have:x⊤Ax>0x^\top A x > 0x⊤Ax>0Similarly:

  • Positive semidefinite matrix:x⊤Ax≥0x^\top A x \geq 0x⊤Ax≥0
  • Negative definite matrix:x⊤Ax<0x^\top A x < 0x⊤Ax<0
  • Semi-negative definite matrix:x⊤Ax≤0x^\top A x \leq 0x⊤Ax≤0
  • Indefinite matrix: can take either positive or negative values

8.3.2 Positive certainty of eigenvalue judgment

If matrixAAAAll eigenvalues ​​of are greater than 0, thenAAARight concentration. Similarly, for other situations, it can be judged as positive semi-definite, semi-negative certain, negative certain, or indefinite.

8.3.3 Sylvester discrimination method

Core conclusion: Real symmetric matrixAAA$The necessary and sufficient conditions for positive definiteness are: all leading principal minors are positive numbers.

Sequential principal formula:Δk=det⁡(Ak),k=1,2,…,n\Delta_k = \det(A_k), \quad k=1,2,\dots,nΔk​=det(Ak​),k=1,2,…,ninAkA_kAk​is a matrixAAAbeforek×kk \times kk×kThe upper left submatrix.

Discrimination rules:

  • likeΔ1>0,Δ2>0,…,Δn>0\Delta_1 > 0, \Delta_2 > 0, \dots, \Delta_n > 0Δ1​>0,Δ2​>0,…,Δn​>0,butAAARight concentration.
  • likeΔ1<0,Δ2>0,Δ3<0,…\Delta_1 < 0, \Delta_2 > 0, \Delta_3 < 0, \dotsΔ1​<0,Δ2​>0,Δ3​<0,…alternating signs, thenAAANegative determination.
  • If some of the principal and sub-formulas are 0, it may be positive semi-definite or negative semi-definite and requires further analysis.
  • If the symbols do not satisfy the above rules, the matrix is ​​indefinite.

Example: AssumeA=[2−10−12−10−12]A = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & -1 & 0 \\ -1 & 2 & -1 \\ 0 & -1 & 2 \end{bmatrix}A=​2−10​−12−1​0−12​​Then there are:

  • Δ1=2>0\Delta_1 = 2 > 0Δ1​=2>0
  • Δ2=det⁡[2−1−12]=3>0\Delta_2 = \det\begin{bmatrix}2 & -1 \\ -1 & 2\end{bmatrix} = 3 > 0Δ2​=det[2−1​−12​]=3>0
  • Δ3=det⁡(A)=4>0\Delta_3 = \det(A) = 4 > 0Δ3​=det(A)=4>0
    thereforeAAAis a positive definite matrix.

9 Applications and Extensions

9.1 Least squares method

In many cases we need to solve a system of linear equations:Ax=bAx=bAx=bin:

  • AAAyesm×nm \times nm×nmatrix (usuallym>nm > nm>n, there are more equations than unknowns)
  • xxxis an unknown vector
  • bbbis the observation data vector

If the system of equations has no solution, we want to find an approximate solution that minimizes the error. Let there be a residual vectorrrrmaking vectorr=b−Axr = b - Axr=b−AxThe approximate solution can be found by minimizing the length of . The objective function here is:f(x)=∥b−Ax∥2=(b−Ax)T(b−Ax)f(x) = \|b - Ax\|^2 = (b - Ax)^T(b - Ax)f(x)=∥b−Ax∥2=(b−Ax)T(b−Ax)Take the derivative with respect to x:∇f(x)=−2AT(b−Ax)\nabla f(x) = -2A^T(b - Ax)∇f(x)=−2AT(b−Ax)Let it be zero:AT(b−Ax)=0A^T(b - Ax) = 0AT(b−Ax)=0Get the Normal Equation:ATAx=ATbA^T A x = A^T bATAx=ATbThis is the core equation of the least squares solution. In a geometric sense, the least squares solution isbbborthogonally projected toAAAOn the column space, get the closest point.

9.4 Singular value decomposition (SVD)

Singular value decomposition is a method of decomposing any matrix into the product of three matrices. The core formula is:A=UΣVTA = U \Sigma V^TA=UΣVT

inUUUandVVVis an orthogonal matrix,Σ\SigmaΣis a diagonal matrix containing singular values. Singular values ​​are matricesATAA^TAATAorAATAA^TAATThe square roots of the eigenvalues, usually in descending order.
